commentMessage:
Great article thank you. 

Just one missing line I needed to add to run the whole tutorial w/o error : 

from sklearn.metrics import confusion_matrix

The tutorial produced very nice looking graphics and is an easy to understand treatment of this well known dataset. 

Jason

Very good tutorial! Intuitive and practical lessons!




I just had one doubt about the histogram part.

According to the author there were only unimodal distributions.

However, I believe the distribution of petal-length is multimodal.

Nice and easy introductory tutorial, very good for beginners like me.

One issue:

 "With just a few lines of code, you were able to train an ML model that  is now able to tell you the flower name by using only four features with  96.66% accuracy. "

Actually only three features were used in the model.

 

train_data,test_data,train_label,test_label = train_test_split(dataset.iloc[:,:3], dataset.iloc[:,4], test_size=0.2, random_state=42)

 

train_data.shape,train_label.shape,test_data.shape,test_label.shape

 

((120, 3), (120,), (30, 3), (30,))

When the last feature is included, the accuracy plot looks very different.

Great Article! This was a really comprehensive, detailed, and helpful tutorial, especially as an introduction to machine learning. I was wondering, when choosing the k-value for optimization, why did you not use k=9? Based on my graph, k=9 seems to exhibit most accurate results, and when I run the algorithm with k=9 upon the test-set, it exhibits 100% accuracy. Is it because both test_accuracy=training_accuracy when k=3?

Thank you,

Dhruv
